Title:
Impatiens shimianensis sp. nov. (Balsaminaceae): A new
species from southwest China based on morphological and molecular
evidence
Keywords:
AtpB-rbcL sequence, Balsaminaceae, Impatiens shimianensis,
ITS sequence, Sichuan
Abstract:
A new species, Impatiens shimianensis (Balsaminaceae), is
described and illustrated. Impatiens shimianensis is morphologically
most similar to I. delavayi in having ovate or ovate-orbicular leaf
shape, crenate leaf margins, and bilobed spurs. The two species differ
in that I. shimianensis has orbicular upper petal of lateral united
petals and very shortly clawed lateral united petals while I. delavayi
has subtetragonous upper petal of lateral united petals and
conspicuously clawed lateral united petals. The upper portion of the
lower sepal of I. shimianensis is yellow and the lower portion of the
lower sepal has brown stripes, whereas the whole lower sepal of I.
delavayi is dark purple or pink. In addition, the petals of I.
shimianensis are yellow or whitish yellow whereas those of I. delavayi
are dirty yellow or pink. Phylogenetic analyses based on DNA sequences
from the nuclear internal transcribed spacer (ITS) and the chloroplast
atpB-rbcL intergenic spacer showed that I. shimianensis formed a
well-supported clade comprising of I. barbata, I. corchorifolia, I.
delavayi, and I. poculifer. In addition to these species, a few other
morphologically related but molecular-phylogenetically unsampled species
were also compared with the species newly discovered. Impatiens
shimianensis can easily be distinguished morphologically from all these
species by having yellowish white flowers, dark red spur tip, and purple
abaxial leaf surface.
